conclusion: Objects A and B start moving from the same location in the same direction.
The x-axis represents time (t) and the y-axis represents velocity (v).
The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration of the object.
At t = t1, Object A is at the origin on the velocity-time graph.
The slope of the line representing Object A at t1 is positive but decreasing.
This indicates that Object A is accelerating.
At t = t1, Object B is also at the origin on the velocity-time graph.
The slope of the curve representing Object B at t1 is negative but decreasing.
This indicates that Object B is decelerating.
The slope of the line for Object A at t1 is positive.
The slope of the curve for Object B at t1 is negative.
Since the slopes are different in magnitude and direction, the accelerations are not the same.
No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time t1.
